body: The logo is now hidden if it fails to load, so you don't see the 'broken image' icon.

- First impression is that it seems too small, especially in comparison to the other items on that line. For example, it seems only 1/3 of the width of the text in the pull-down list, and maybe only 1/7 of the size of the "IP[y] Notebook" logo. Arguably, the kernel is the most salient factor to the user.
- Perhaps the text in the pull-down list need not be displayed as one should be able to tell from the banner what kernel is being used. The pull down list could just be the down-arrow, with the named choices popup listed when you click it.
- Perhaps the pull down list could be composed of the banner images (may be an issue for text readers though)
- It is so small, it is hard to read... now with the menu behaving better on my cell phone, it looks good, but banner can't be read

The header area is probably going to see some redesign, which might make more space for it. We want to keep the kernel logo square, though, so it's not tied to a particular layout.

We have also thought of including small (16x16) logos in the kernel dropdown menu alongside the names, but I like to do things one step at a time.

- I am fine moving forward with merging this before the final design work is done.
- As I understand it, we have plans to remove the kernel selection UI from the notebook (other than in the Kernel Menu). So I vote -1 on putting the language logo in the area permanently.
- When I have talked to folks about this previously, we had talked about the language logo as being part of the "branding," and as such would be over by the main jupyter logo in the L portion of the site header.
Also please @ mention me on UI related things - I am not subscribed to everything any longer.
Flagging as needs decision
If this gets a rebase, I think it can be merged as-is to get logo support landed, and we can workout the layout later.

> If this gets a rebase, I think it can be merged as-is to get logo support landed, and we can workout the layout later.

+1
Great! Wonder if you want to make the file name be logo-32x32.png? Hoping that some day it can be wider... so there could be a logo-32x128.png or something in the future.
@dsblank I don't think we are going to have any large kernel logos on the page, only small ones.

Rebased, and checked that it still works.

We should work out what to do about hires displays. We presumably need a double-size icon, so 64x64 pixels, to draw at 32 pixels. Should the naming follow the display size or the actual image size?
I think the name should reflect the actual image resolution-  If the UI needs to display a 64x64 image in a 32x32 area for it to look good, that's the UI's business.

@jdfreder it's more complicated than that in practice. It is common, for instance, to have a `32x32@2x.png` file, which is for display at 32x32 on 2x displays. A 64px image meant to display at 64px and a 64px image meant to display at 32px can differ, e.g. removing small features. Just because a small feature can be resolved in 64 physical pixels doesn't necessarily mean it should be displayed at 32 logical pixels.

Maybe we don't go that far in the spec we provide, but it's not that simple.

(Using 32x32 as an example)
Ah, thanks for clarifying, I didn't realize that and I understand now, but that doesn't change my opinion.  There's no point in having both 32x32 and 32x32@2x images, unless you want to be explicit about the image's resampling. Therefor I think all of the images should be 32x32@2 (named half of true resolution and suffixed with @2) _OR_ 64x64 (named after true resolution).  I still prefer the later, but don't have a strong opinion.
OK, it now uses `logo-64.png`, displayed at 32x32 px using CSS.
Given the sizes of logo images, I think it's appropriate to display at 2x everywhere, which simplifies things. Naming with true resolution works for me.
As suggested, the files are now named like `logo-64x64.png`, making it obvious how to do non-square logos if we need to.
Works for me.

Looks nice!

![screenshot from 2014-12-09 18 24 33](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/168568/5368175/dd2f4126-7fd0-11e4-99ff-42b06e556dbd.png)
Ha, love that logo Doug!
Why, thank you :) I have no artistic skills, but I can write code! This is the Heighway Dragon (two of them actually) as the Python snakes. @blink1073 and I thought about logos for way too long :)

> Why, thank you :) I have no artistic skills, but I can write code! This is the Heighway Dragon (two of them actually) as the Python snakes. @blink1073 and I thought about logos for way too long :)

Sweet, the drawing would make a nice loading animation.

Did something break with this in master? I'm getting 404's now:

```
[W 10:21:19.541 NotebookApp] 404 GET /kernelspecs/python2/logo-64x64.png (127.0.0.1) 10.10ms referer=http://localhost:8888/notebooks/Untitled2.ipynb
```
@dsblank I am seeing the same issue. The logo works as expected for external kernels (python2 and R in python3 etc) but not the kernel that matches the python version that IPython runs with.
@jenshnielsen Ah, you are right... I see the logos for other kernels. Thanks for confirming! I wasn't sure if I had somehow corrupted my installation.
You need to use `ipython kernelspec install-self` for both python2 and python3 I guess.
Although, I don't see external kernel logos running jupyterhub. @minrk do you see logos there? I getting 404's for all kernel logos.

@Carreau  That just results in `[Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/IPython/kernel/resources'` since it is trying to install the resources from a directory which does not exist.

I did `python2 -m IPython kernelspec install-self --system` like the docker file to install the resources for external kernels. This works as expected but only for external kernels.

I.e. for python2 this is found 

```
http://localhost:8888/kernelspecs/python3/logo-64x64.png
```

but not 

```
http://localhost:8888/kernelspecs/python2/logo-64x64.png
```

even thou both kernel specs are installed.

For python3 the situation is reversed.

The same is true for the kernel.json file 

```
http://localhost:8888/kernelspecs/python3/kernel.json
```

For the native kernel (the one that will run with the same Python as the server), it serves up the resources from a directory inside the IPython installation. I wouldn't be surprised if we forgot to add the data files in that directory to the installation - I have IPython symlinked from the repository to site-packages so I'm always using what I have checked out, but that means I don't see installation issues. Will investigate now.
